terms.definition: A type of cell division that results in two daughter cells each having the same number and kind of chromosomes as the parent nucleus.
terms.subject: Biology

terms.definition: The process by which green plants and some other organisms use sunlight to synthesize foods from carbon dioxide and water.
terms.subject: Biology

terms.definition: The tendency toward a relatively stable equilibrium between interdependent elements, especially as maintained by physiological processes.
terms.subject: Biology

terms.definition: One of two or more alternative forms of a gene that arise by mutation and are found at the same place on a chromosome.
terms.subject: Biology

terms.definition: A process by which molecules of a solvent pass through a semipermeable membrane from a less concentrated solution into a more concentrated one.
terms.subject: Biology

terms.definition: A minute particle consisting of RNA and associated proteins found in large numbers in the cytoplasm of living cells.
terms.subject: Biology

terms.definition: A substance produced by a living organism which acts as a catalyst to bring about a specific biochemical reaction.
terms.subject: Biology

terms.definition: A biological community of interacting organisms and their physical environment.
terms.subject: Biology

terms.definition: The set of observable characteristics of an individual resulting from the interaction of its genotype with the environment.
terms.subject: Biology

terms.definition: The process whereby organisms better adapted to their environment tend to survive and produce more offspring.
terms.subject: Biology

terms.definition: A diploid cell resulting from the fusion of two haploid gametes; a fertilized ovum.
terms.subject: Biology

terms.definition: The rate of change of velocity per unit of time.
terms.subject: Physics

terms.definition: Energy which a body possesses by virtue of being in motion.
terms.subject: Physics

terms.definition: The fact or phenomenon of light, radio waves, etc. being deflected in passing obliquely through the interface between one medium and another.
terms.subject: Physics

terms.definition: The branch of physical science that deals with the relations between heat and other forms of energy.
terms.subject: Physics

terms.definition: A quantity having direction as well as magnitude, especially as determining the position of one point in space relative to another.
terms.subject: Physics

terms.definition: The quantity of motion of a moving body, measured as a product of its mass and velocity.
terms.subject: Physics

terms.definition: A property of matter by which it continues in its existing state of rest or uniform motion in a straight line, unless that state is changed by an external force.
terms.subject: Physics

terms.definition: The force that attracts a body toward the center of the earth, or toward any other physical body having mass.
terms.subject: Physics

terms.definition: A flow of electricity which results from the ordered directional movement of electrically charged particles.
terms.subject: Physics

terms.definition: The maximum extent of a vibration or oscillation, measured from the position of equilibrium.
terms.subject: Physics

terms.definition: The resistance that one surface or object encounters when moving over another.
terms.subject: Physics

terms.definition: A chemical bond that involves the sharing of electron pairs between atoms.
terms.subject: Chemistry

terms.definition: The relationship between the relative quantities of substances taking part in a reaction or forming a compound.
terms.subject: Chemistry

terms.definition: A logarithmic scale used to specify the acidity or basicity of an aqueous solution.
terms.subject: Chemistry

terms.definition: Each of two or more forms of the same element that contain equal numbers of protons but different numbers of neutrons.
terms.subject: Chemistry

terms.definition: A substance that increases the rate of a chemical reaction without itself undergoing any permanent chemical change.
terms.subject: Chemistry

terms.definition: The SI unit of amount of substance, equal to the quantity containing as many elementary entities as there are atoms in 0.012 kg of carbon-12.
terms.subject: Chemistry

terms.definition: The process or result of oxidizing or being oxidized; loss of electrons during a reaction.
terms.subject: Chemistry

terms.definition: A liquid mixture in which the minor component (the solute) is uniformly distributed within the major component (the solvent).
terms.subject: Chemistry

terms.definition: An electron in the outer shell of an atom which can participate in the formation of a chemical bond.
terms.subject: Chemistry

terms.definition: A reaction or process accompanied by the release of heat.
terms.subject: Chemistry

terms.definition: A substance that has a molecular structure consisting chiefly or entirely of a large number of similar units bonded together.
terms.subject: Chemistry

terms.definition: The revival of art and literature under the influence of classical models in the 14th–16th centuries.
terms.subject: History

terms.definition: The dominant social system in medieval Europe, in which the nobility held lands from the Crown in exchange for military service.
terms.subject: History

terms.definition: The rapid development of industry that occurred in Britain in the late 18th and 19th centuries, brought about by the introduction of machinery.
terms.subject: History

terms.definition: The state of political hostility that existed between the Soviet bloc countries and the US-led Western powers from 1945 to 1990.
terms.subject: History

terms.definition: A policy of extending a country's power and influence through diplomacy or military force.
terms.subject: History

terms.definition: A charter of liberties to which the English barons forced King John to give his assent in June 1215.
terms.subject: History

terms.definition: A policy or system of segregation or discrimination on grounds of race, formerly in force in South Africa.
terms.subject: History

terms.definition: A network of trade routes connecting the East and West, central to the economic, cultural, political, and religious interactions between these regions.
terms.subject: History

terms.definition: The treaty signed in 1919 that brought a formal end to World War I.
terms.subject: History

terms.definition: The right to vote in political elections.
terms.subject: History

terms.definition: A 16th-century movement for the reform of abuses in the Roman Catholic Church ending in the establishment of the Reformed and Protestant Churches.
terms.subject: History

terms.definition: A theory explaining the structure of the earth's crust and many associated phenomena as resulting from the interaction of rigid lithospheric plates.
terms.subject: Geography

terms.definition: The process of making an area more urban, involving the migration of populations from rural to urban areas.
terms.subject: Geography

terms.definition: The angular distance of a place north or south of the earth's equator.
terms.subject: Geography

terms.definition: A large naturally occurring community of flora and fauna occupying a major habitat, e.g., forest or tundra.
terms.subject: Geography

terms.definition: The statistical study of populations, especially human beings.
terms.subject: Geography

terms.definition: The process of eroding or being eroded by wind, water, or other natural agents.
terms.subject: Geography

terms.definition: A seasonal prevailing wind in the region of South and Southeast Asia, bringing rain.
terms.subject: Geography

terms.definition: The process by which businesses or other organizations develop international influence or start operating on an international scale.
terms.subject: Geography

terms.definition: The science or practice of drawing maps.
terms.subject: Geography

terms.definition: The time or date (twice each year) at which the sun crosses the celestial equator, when day and night are of equal length.
terms.subject: Geography

terms.definition: A vast, flat, treeless Arctic region of Europe, Asia, and North America in which the subsoil is permanently frozen.
terms.subject: Geography

terms.definition: The amount of a commodity, product, or service available and the desire of buyers for it, considered as factors regulating its price.
terms.subject: Economics

terms.definition: A general increase in prices and fall in the purchasing value of money.
terms.subject: Economics

terms.definition: Gross Domestic Product: the total value of goods produced and services provided in a country during one year.
terms.subject: Economics

terms.definition: The loss of potential gain from other alternatives when one alternative is chosen.
terms.subject: Economics

terms.definition: The exclusive possession or control of the supply of or trade in a commodity or service.
terms.subject: Economics

terms.definition: The use of government spending and tax policies to influence economic conditions.
terms.subject: Economics

terms.definition: The availability of liquid assets to a market or company; the ease with which an asset can be converted into ready cash.
terms.subject: Economics

terms.definition: A tax or duty to be paid on a particular class of imports or exports.
terms.subject: Economics

terms.definition: The state of being scarce or in short supply; shortage.
terms.subject: Economics

terms.definition: The proportion of a loan that is charged as interest to the borrower, typically expressed as an annual percentage of the loan outstanding.
terms.subject: Economics

terms.definition: A period of temporary economic decline during which trade and industrial activity are reduced.
terms.subject: Economics

terms.definition: A fundamental relation in Euclidean geometry among the three sides of a right triangle: a² + b² = c².
terms.subject: Mathematics

terms.definition: Any equation that can be rearranged in standard form as ax² + bx + c = 0.
terms.subject: Mathematics

terms.definition: The instantaneous rate of change of a function with respect to one of its variables.
terms.subject: Mathematics

terms.definition: A whole number; a number that is not a fraction.
terms.subject: Mathematics

terms.definition: The average of a set of numbers, calculated by adding them together and dividing by the number of items in the set.
terms.subject: Mathematics

terms.definition: An expression of more than two algebraic terms, especially the sum of several terms that contain different powers of the same variable(s).
terms.subject: Mathematics

terms.definition: A number that describes both the direction and the steepness of the line.
terms.subject: Mathematics

terms.definition: A quantity representing the power to which a fixed number (the base) must be raised to produce a given number.
terms.subject: Mathematics

terms.definition: A triangle that has at least two sides of equal length.
terms.subject: Mathematics

terms.definition: The extent to which an event is likely to occur, measured by the ratio of the favorable cases to the whole number of cases possible.
terms.subject: Mathematics

terms.definition: A symbol (usually a letter) standing in for an unknown numerical value in an equation.
terms.subject: Mathematics

terms.definition: A figure of speech in which a word or phrase is applied to an object or action to which it is not literally applicable.
terms.subject: English

terms.definition: A figure of speech involving the comparison of one thing with another thing of a different kind, used to make a description more emphatic or vivid (e.g., as brave as a lion).
terms.subject: English

terms.definition: Exaggerated statements or claims not meant to be taken literally.
terms.subject: English

terms.definition: The occurrence of the same letter or sound at the beginning of adjacent or closely connected words.
terms.subject: English

terms.definition: The expression of one's meaning by using language that normally signifies the opposite, typically for humorous or emphatic effect.
terms.subject: English

terms.definition: The leading character or one of the major characters in a drama, movie, novel, or other fictional text.
terms.subject: English

terms.definition: An idea that recurs in or pervades a work of art or literature.
terms.subject: English

terms.definition: The formation of a word from a sound associated with what is named (e.g., cuckoo, sizzle).
terms.subject: English

terms.definition: The arrangement of words and phrases to create well-formed sentences in a language.
terms.subject: English

terms.definition: The attribution of a personal nature or human characteristics to something nonhuman.
terms.subject: English

terms.definition: A figure of speech in which apparently contradictory terms appear in conjunction.
terms.subject: English

terms.definition: Lasting for a very short time.
terms.subject: SAT

terms.definition: Unnecessary, especially through being more than enough.
terms.subject: SAT

terms.definition: Well meaning and kindly.
terms.subject: SAT

terms.definition: Provide evidence to support or prove the truth of.
terms.subject: SAT

terms.definition: Tending to keep a firm hold of something; clinging or adhering closely.
terms.subject: SAT

terms.definition: A thing belonging or appropriate to a period other than that in which it exists, especially a thing that is conspicuously old-fashioned.
terms.subject: SAT

terms.definition: Acting with or showing care and thought for the future.
terms.subject: SAT

terms.definition: Restore friendly relations between.
terms.subject: SAT

terms.definition: Deceitful and untrustworthy.
terms.subject: SAT

terms.definition: Lacking interest or excitement; dull.
terms.subject: SAT

terms.definition: Certain to happen; unavoidable.
terms.subject: SAT

terms.definition: Long life; long existence or service.
terms.subject: SAT
